discussion.content: Answer is A: The question states that the host has 24 logical cores, not physical.

A virtual machine cannot have more virtual CPUs than the number of logical cores on the host.

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/6.0/com.vmware.vsphere.html.hostclient.doc/GUID-13AD347E-3B77-4A67-B3F4-4AC2230E4509.html?hWord=N4IghgNiBcIQ9gcwJYGNIAJXwE4FMBnEAXyA
The correct would not be 48? Since hyperthreading is twice as many cores

questions.question_text:
An ESXi 6.x host consists of 24 logical cores. Hyperthreading is enabled on the host.
What is the maximum number of vCPUs that can be assigned to a virtual machine on this host?

choices.D: The vCenter Server must be in the same single Sign-On domain.
choices.E: The ESXi hosts must have vSphere Standard, Advanced, or Enterprise Plus licensing.
choices.B: The ESXi hosts must be version 5.5 or later.
choices.C: The vCenter Servers must be version 6.0 or later.
choices.A: The vCenter Server servers must be time-synchronized.

questions.question_text: Which two options are requirements to perform a migration between vCenter Server instances? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: Answer is correct. As per the reference shared above: if the vCenter Server instances exist in separate vCenter Single Sign-On domains, you can use vSphere APIs/SDK to migrate virtual machines
That reference also states that they need to be part of the same SSO domain, making D correct as well. And time sync is required for proper SSO token verification.
AD, For more troubleshooting information, see the SSO_SERVER\utils\logs\imsTrace.log, install.log, and %TEMP%\vminstall.log files.

questions.question_text:
An administrator attempts to install vCenter Single Sign-On Server. The installer returns an error message indicating that the installation failed. Prior to the installation, all setup prerequisites were met. The administrator has generated a vCenter Server Single Sign-On support bundle.
Which two files should the administrator analyze to determine the cause of the failure? (Choose two.)

When attempting to access a virtual machine, an administrator is unable to login using the vSphere credentials.
What two options are probable causes of the authentication failure? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: Correct answer A & C. A user logging in with Read Only access, does not give authentication failure.

choices.B: The vSphere credentials are granted read-only permissions.
choices.C: The vSphere credentials are granted no-access permissions.
choices.D: The vSphere credentials are not a member of the local administrator group.
choices.A: The vSphere credentials have not been granted permissions.

questions.question_text: When modifying a vApp, which two vSphere entities can be added? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
must be A&C: 
Create a Virtual Machine, Resource Pool, or Child vApp Inside a vApp - https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/6.5/com.vmware.vsphere.vm_admin.doc/GUID-12FDA1A4-6214-463B-8D73-FE25454C642E.html

comments.content: Question is about what can be added while modifying an existing vApp so A,B are more appropriate. Child vApp is added as a separate object through right-click.
